item.title: D1: plating cells
item.description:
2.2.0 BHK plaque assay protocol v1 // timeline: 5 days (plating to staining)




BHK media
5mL 5% trypsin
10mL PBS
10¬µL trypan blue


0.5mL centrifuge tube
hemacytometer
counting slides
6- or 12-well plates (# determined by cell count-based calc.)


BHK cell culture (in T75 flask*) ~90-100% confluency



Discard old media & wash cells with 10mL PBS in culture vessel
Discard PBS & trypsinize cells with
MIX WELL with 5 mL trypsin
(Optional) incubate for ~5m & confirm cleavage under microscope
Count detached, freshly re-suspended cells in hemacytometer
**Inserted code template - Enter values below and get V2 instantly:**
Prepare adequate solution for n plates adjusted to target concentration
~12n+2 mL
Mix prepared cell suspension thoroughly with pipette aspiration
Pipette 2mL of well-mixed solution into each well of 6-well plate
for 12-well plate, 1 mL/well; for 24-well plate, 0.5 mL/well
(optional) Let plate settle at RT for ~20m ‚Üí incubate @ 37¬∫C overnight

Enter values below and get V2 instantly:
cell count A:
cell count B:
available volume (V1 in mL):
target concentration (C2 in cells/mL):
Calculate C1 (avg. cell count): -- V2 (mL of total possible target diltion): -- n (max # of plates): --




BHK media
2% LMP agarose
2X MEM


water bath (56¬∞C)
96-well plate
(optional) multichannel pipette
6- or 12-well plates (# determined by cell count-based calc.)


plated BHK cultures
designated concentrated viral titer


Thaw concentrated viral titer(s)
disregard any excess virus; NO REFREEZE
Label BHK plates with desired dilution series
e.g. (for 6-well plate) 0 ‚Üí -5, -1 ‚Üí -6, -2 ‚Üí -7
Melt 2% LMP ‚Üí leave in 56¬∞C water bath
Bring 2X MEM to room temp
Prepare 6 serial dilutions (per plate)
pipette 180 ¬µL BHK media (x6/plate)
add 20 ¬µL concentrated virus to 180 ¬µL media
mix with pipette aspiration & repeat for remaining series, sequentially transferring 20 ¬µL to designated wells
Add 150 ¬µL of each dilution to appropriate well of 6-well plate
100 ¬µL for 12-well plate
Rotate plate to evenly cover monolayer
Incubate @ 37¬∞C for 1hr (set timer!)
After incubation, prepare 1:1 mix of 2X MEM and 2% LMP agarose
3 mL/well (+ 2 mL for error)
üìç write calc code block based on "n" from D1
(optional) add ~extra LMP to correct for viscosity
Swiftly but gently pipette 3 mL of mix per well

item.title: 1.3.0 chemical abbreviations
item.description:
& SDS? add links to drive files or upload pdfs


Uses
Cell culture: PBS is used in cell culture manufacturing and upstream process development. It's isotonic, which means it prevents cells from rupturing or shriveling. 
Cell enumeration: PBS is used as a diluent to enumerate cells. 
Rinsing cells: PBS is used to rinse cells. 
Biochemical and cellular assays: PBS is used as a buffer in many biochemical and cellular assays. 
Western blotting and ELISA: PBS containing Tween 20 is used as a blocking agent in western blotting and Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) techniques. 
Preparation 

PBS can be prepared by using commercially made PBS buffer tablets or pouches.
The pH of PBS is around 7.4. You can adjust the pH using hydrochloric acid or sodium hydroxide.
PBS can be stored at room temperature or in the refrigerator.

item.title: 1.5.0 ELN organizational practices
item.description:
real-time updates
üìç ask about flexibility re: digital notes & hygiene
ensure standardized formatting
date entries following clear experiment descriptor


review & summarize weekly results
cross-check used reagents/materials with inventory [records]
backup data & manage labeled folders
include diagrams, flowcharts, photos, etc. to complement procedures or observations


back up vault & all data in multiple locations
e.g. lab gdrive, hard-drive, uncc server
review month's entries to ensure completion & consistency
review long-term projects ‚Üí track milestones & deviations


use fully linked index system for quick navigation
with index labeling system, cross-ref experiments assoc. with raw files or reports


for iterative exp. designs, add unambiguous version label (e.g. V1.2, V2.0)
archive old versions but ensure only latest protocols are actively used


re: security & Obsidian structure


share notebook with lab-mates for constructive feedback
clarify my workflow & ensure continuous accessibility to updated notes

item.title: 2.1.1 general cell culture
item.description:
AET 1.27.25 üîí
objective: grow healthy cell cultures as reliable foundation for in vitro experiments & controlled study of cell behavior and interactions
Timeline: ~30m





cell-specific media
Trypan blue (for cell counts)


T25 (for P0)
25 cm¬≤ culture flask
option for T75 or T175 starting with P1
waste beaker (1:10 bleach sln)
0.5mL tube 
cell count slides
hemacytometer
70% ethanol


1 vial of desired cell line

add specifics and clarify any deviations from standard protocol 


Locate appropriate media for cell line or prepare
Locate cell line via ‚ÄòItemized List of Lab Contents‚Äô sheet in Funk Lab GDrive folder
4 tabs for corresponding liquid nitrogen racks
Thaw vial in 37¬∞C water bath with gentle agitation (~2min)
keep O-ring & cap out of water to reduce contamination risk Ôªø
Promptly remove thawed vial from water and decontaminate by spraying or dipping in 70% ethanol
‚Äî proceed under strict sterile conditions within BSC ‚Äî
In 15mL centrifuge tube, transfer vial contents over 9.0 mL of complete culture medium
Spin @ 125 x g for 5min
Discard supernatant & add 5 mL fresh media back to 15mL tube
Re-suspend pellet with repeated pipette aspiration and dispense contents into T25 culture flask
(optional, to reduce risk of alkaline damage during cell recovery & encourage appropriate pH) prior to adding vial contents, put culture vessel containing media in CO2 incubator for ~15min
Label flask with cell line name, passage #, initials, & date of procedure
Incubate culture at 37¬∞C in a suitable incubator (5% CO2 typically recommended for medium described)


Discard old growth media &
Briefly wash with 5 mL of sterile PBS then discard into liquid waste
Add 2 mL trypsin & incubate ~5min for complete detachment
P0 ‚Üí P1 Prep

e.g. BHK or L929 cells


ÔªøÔªøÔªøDiscard old growth media
Briefly wash culture with ~10 mL PBS
Gentle figure-8 flask movement (x3) ‚Äî> discard wash
ÔªøÔªøÔªøAdd 3.0 mL of Trypsin-EDTA solution to culture flask and incubate for ~5min
(üìç try 2min before observation)
Observe cells under an inverted microscope to confirm cell layer dispersal
!! To avoid clumping, do not hit or shake flask to encourage cells to detach ‚Äî add incubation time or (last resort) +1 mL trypsin
Add 10 - 15 mL of complete growth medium and aspirate cells using gentle pipetting
Add appropriate amount of cell suspension to new culture vessel
If sterility is maintained, add/ensure appropriate amount of growth medium to current vessel (for single-reuse)

general primary culture recommendation ‚Äî 1:2
generally, no lower than 1:20 for culture viability

item.title: D1: plating cells
item.description:
objective: visualize viral activity & quantify concentration of viral particles in a sample through plaque formation following inoculation
plaques ‚â° areas of cell death induced by viral infection
Timeline: 5days, from prep to staining D1 : ~60min for plating
D2: ~2hr to complete infection
D5: >60m for fixing + <5m for staining




BHK media
5mL 5% trypsin
10mL PBS
10¬µL trypan blue


0.5mL centrifuge tube
hemacytometer
counting slides
6- or 12-well plates
# based on cell count calc.


BHK cell culture (in T75 flask*) ~90-100% confluency



Discard old media & wash cells with 10mL PBS in culture vessel
Discard PBS & trypsinize cells with
MIX WELL with 5 mL trypsin
(Optional) incubate for ~5m & confirm cleavage under microscope
Count detached, freshly re-suspended cells in hemacytometer
**Inserted code template - Enter values below and get V2 instantly:**
Prepare adequate solution for n plates adjusted to target concentration
~12n+2 mL
Mix prepared cell suspension thoroughly with pipette aspiration
Pipette 2mL of well-mixed solution into each well of 6-well plate
for 12-well plate, 1 mL/well; for 24-well plate, 0.5 mL/well
(optional) Let plate settle at RT for ~20m ‚Üí incubate @ 37¬∫C overnight

Enter values below and get V2 instantly:
cell count A:
cell count B:
available volume (V1 in mL):
target concentration (C2 in cells/mL):
Calculate C1 (avg. cell count): -- V2 (mL of total possible target diltion): -- n (max # of plates): --




BHK media
2% LMP agarose
2X MEM


water bath (56¬∞C)
96-well plate
(optional) multichannel pipette
6- or 12-well plates (# determined by cell count-based calc.)


plated BHK cultures
designated concentrated viral titer


Thaw concentrated viral titer(s)
disregard any excess virus; NO REFREEZE
Label BHK plates with desired dilution series
e.g. (for 6-well plate) 0 ‚Üí -5, -1 ‚Üí -6, -2 ‚Üí -7
Melt 2% LMP ‚Üí leave in 56¬∞C water bath
Bring 2X MEM to room temp
Prepare 6 serial dilutions (per plate)
pipette 180 ¬µL BHK media (x6/plate)
add 20 ¬µL concentrated virus to 180 ¬µL media
mix well & repeat for remaining series (move 20 ¬µL sequentially down designated wells)
Add 150 ¬µL of each dilution to appropriate well of 6-well plate
100 ¬µL for 12-well plate
Rotate plate to evenly cover monolayer
Incubate @ 37¬∞C for 1hr (set timer!)
After incubation, prepare 1:1 mix of 2X MEM and 2% LMP agarose
3 mL/well (+ 2 mL for error)
üìç write calc code block based on "n" from D1
(optional) add ~extra LMP to correct for viscosity
Swiftly but gently pipette 3 mL of mix per well
WITH CONCENTRATED VIRUS

Thaw viral titer @ RT & melt agarose in microwave ~2m
Keep agarose in 56¬∫C water bath or hot plate to keep thawed
Prepare 6 serial dilutions, starting with 20 ¬µL

item.title: 2.4.3 embedding & sectioning brains v1
item.description:
AET 1.24.25 üîí
objective: cryopreserving mouse brains and sectioning to 10 microns* for staining *: adjust section thickness as needed/recommended
Timeline: ~30m



OCT 
Ice-it


Dry ice (box in ‚Äì80 freezer) 
Diaper pad 
Aluminum foil
Sterile Erlenmeyer flask
Small beaker (for waste)
Tweezers 
Embedding molds (plastic cubes)
Address labels


Mouse brains (sagittal-cut, suspended in sucrose)

add specifics and clarify any deviations from standard protocol 

Poke Ice-It nozzle through foil of Erlenmeyer flask 
Spray generously to gather liquid to support freeze & cover bottom-third of cubes 
Pour liquid into small open container and enclose in dry ice box 
Label embedding mold to match to available samples 
Write on un-slanted side 
Write "OFC" on opposite side 
Fill labeled molds with OCT ~¬æ-‚Öò full 
Place into Ice-It container over dry ice & allow to solidify (look for fully frozen bottom) 
Gently discard sucrose into waste beaker & leave brain on diaper pad 
With tweezers, gently roll tissue on diaper pad to remove excess moisture 
Once OCT solidifies, place brain into gel, orienting orbitofrontal cortex to 'OFC'-labeled side 
Align brain parallel to bottom for even slicing 
Return cube to Ice-It container to fully solidify (until brain is not visible from the top) 
Once OCT fully solidifies (brain is not visible from the top), cover cube with foil 
Re-label with red address labels on top of foil 
Rest in dry ice (out of Ice-It) while repeating process for following samples 
Store wrapped tissue in -80¬∞C until time for further dissection 4/5

item.title: 8.1.1 misc note dump
item.description:
staging area for organization
general exp. note outline (below)

Project-Based Labeling: Assign a unique project identifier for each experiment series. Example: Proj-AŒ≤-TgMouse-01 (Abeta study in transgenic mice).
Experiment Type Prefixes: Use standard prefixes to differentiate logs quickly:
InVivo-XXX for animal studies
Cell-XXX for cell culture work
Prot-XXX for molecular techniques
Img-XXX for imaging experiments
Data-XXX for raw/processed data
Date Codes: Include the date (YYYYMMDD) for chronological tracking, e.g., Cell-001-20250123.
Version Control for Protocols: Add a version suffix (e.g., RNAExt-V1.2).

[Experiment Type/Category][Project or Protocol Name][Unique ID or Version]_[Optional Date]

category-name-ID-date
cat ‚Üí abbreviation or numbers?
‚â§5 words, consider abbreviations to keep names shorter
linking to protocols could help minimize title info overload...üìçtest HTML usability
unique code/#
date ‚Üí remove from title but add to visible metadata



Experiment Category > Project Name > Unique Identifier
Cell_NeuronalViability_001
Prot_RNAExtraction_V1.1
Data_BehavioralTest_TrialA


Experiment Category > Project Name > Unique Identifier > Date
Cell_NeuronalViability_001_2025-01-23
Prot_WesternBlot_Troubleshooting_2025-01-23
Data_FlowCytometry_CytokineAnalysis_2025-01-23


Header : refNum expTitle yy.mm.dd AET

refNum for tracking continuity
expTitle brief descriptor of activities
start date for multi-day exp.

Purpose/Objective
Write a concise statement describing the aim of the experiment or task.
Materials and Reagents
List all materials, reagents, and equipment needed.
Include specific identifiers like lot numbers, concentrations, or sources for critical reagents.
Protocol/Procedure
Step-by-Step Description: Record each step clearly and sequentially.
Include exact timings, temperatures, volumes, and other parameters.
Note deviations or adjustments in real-time.
Results and Observations
Record raw data (e.g., measurements, images, or graphs).
Describe any unexpected occurrences, visual changes, or procedural challenges.
Paste printouts or attach files (e.g., spectroscopy data, gel images, etc.).
Analysis
Summarize key findings from raw data.
Include calculations, statistical analyses, or plots if relevant.
Highlight trends or potential errors.
Conclusions
Provide a brief statement on whether the experiment met its objectives.
Suggest follow-up actions or adjustments.
Signatures/Verification
Sign and date the entry for authenticity.
Have your PI or supervisor verify and sign if required.

item.dc:creator: AET

item.title: 8.3.1 why Obsidian vs. OneNote for ELN
item.description:
after tackling accessibility concerns with static backups & straightforward sharing (via gitpages), Obsidian is a more flexible & powerful aid for notes and documentation


markdown file base ‚Üí plain text storage for universal accessibility & easy backups
flexible customization, including linking & plug-ins
version control (through git) ‚Üí simple, yet thorough change tracking
portability, i.e. data not locked in proprietary format ‚à¥ accessible without Obsidian & offline


accessibility: regular static backups + web hosting (github)
collaboration: supplement with Google Drive tools for real-time collab or more flexible editing
search & organization: to tackle unfamiliarity with the Obsidian format, use tags, links, and folders intentionally & consistently
supplement with documentation clarifying structure
data security: sensitive data will be stored elsewhere on encrypted drives
long-term accessibility/clarity: maintain static backup of vault in universal format (PDF or HTML)
integration: unlikely to come up but selections from PDF/HTML backup should suffice
1.1.0 Funk Lab index
item.guid: 8.3.1 why Obsidian vs. OneNote for ELN.md
